"Yes, yes... I know it’s really annoying..." Raskolnikov said, but he seemed lost in thought, making Dounia look at him in confusion. 

"What else did I want to say?" He tried to remember. "Oh, right; Mom, and you too, Dounia, please don’t think I didn’t want to see you today and was just waiting for you to come first." 

"What are you talking about, Rodya?" Pulcheria Alexandrovna exclaimed, also surprised. 

"Is he just responding out of obligation?" Dounia wondered. "Is he trying to make up and ask for forgiveness like it’s a ritual or something he practiced?" 

"I just woke up and wanted to come to you, but I was delayed because of my clothes. I forgot to ask Nastasya yesterday to wash out the blood... I just got dressed." 

"Blood! What blood?" Pulcheria Alexandrovna asked, worried. 

"Oh, it’s nothing—don’t worry. It was when I was wandering around yesterday, feeling a bit crazy, and I came across a man who had been run over... a clerk..." 

"Crazy? But you remember everything!" Razumihin interrupted. 

"That’s true," Raskolnikov said carefully. "I remember everything, even the smallest details, but I can’t really explain why I did that or why I went there or said those things." 

"That happens sometimes," Zossimov added. "People can do things very skillfully, yet their thoughts and actions can be all mixed up."

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov struggles to communicate with his family while grappling with his troubled state of mind and a recent traumatic experience.
